Coefficients can be between 0 and 2047 and are stored in bits 0..11, 12..23, ..., 48..59 of a long number.

member.summary: Multiplies the polynomial with a TernaryPolynomial, taking the indices mod N and the values mod 2048.

member.summary: Returns a polynomial that is equal to this polynomial (in the sense that mult(IntegerPolynomial, int) returns equal IntegerPolynomials). The new polynomial is guaranteed to be independent of the original.

summary.h3: PKCS5 V2: An implementation of an Hash based Key Derivation Function.
summary.para: PKCS5 Version 2, as outlined in RFC 2898RFC 2898

item.description: Can be initialized with a Digest or a Mac.
The Constructors DisposeEngine parameter determines if Digest engine is destroyed when is called on this class; default is true.
Salt size should be multiple of Digest block size.
Ikm size should be Digest hash return size.
Nonce and Ikm are optional, (but recommended).
RFC 2898: Specification.
Based on the Bouncy Castle Java Release 1.51 version.

summary.h3: DGTDRBG: An implementation of a Digest Counter based Deterministic Random Byte Generator.
summary.para: A Digest Counter DRBG as outlined in NIST document: SP800-90ASP800-90A

item.description: Can be initialized with any digest.
Combination of [Salt, Ikm, Nonce] must be at least: digest block size + counter (8 bytes) size in length.
The Constructors DisposeEngine parameter determines if Digest engine is destroyed when is called on this class; default is true.
Nonce and Ikm are optional, (but recommended).
Output buffer is 4 * the digest return size.
NIST SP800-90A: Appendix E1.
NIST SP800-90B: Recommendation for the Entropy Sources Used for Random Bit Generation.
NIST Fips 140-2: Security Requirments For Cryptographic Modules.
NIST SP800-22 1a: A Statistical Test Suite for Random and Pseudorandom Number Generators for Cryptographic Applications.
Security Bounds for the NIST Codebook-based: Deterministic Random Bit Generator.
Based on the Bouncy Castle Java Release 1.51 version.

summary.para: Update the Seed material. Three state Seed paramater: If Seed size is equal to digest blocksize plus counter size, both are updated. If Seed size is equal to digest block size, internal state seed is updated. If Seed size is equal to counter size (8 bytes) counter is updated.

summary.h3: SP20Prng: An implementation of a Encryption Counter based Deterministic Random Number Generator.
summary.para: Uses the Salsa20 Key stream as a source of random input.

item.description: Valid Key sizes are 128, 256 (16 and 32 bytes).
Block size is 64 bytes wide.
Parallel block size is 64,000 bytes by default; but is configurable.
Salsa20 Specification.
Salsa20 Design.
Salsa20 Security.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Crypto.Prng.SP20Prng.#ctor(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Crypto.Enumeration.SeedGenerators,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initialize the class
member.param: The Seed engine used to create keyng material (default is CSPRsg)
The size of the cache of random bytes (must be more than 1024 to enable parallel processing)
The size of the seed to generate in bytes; can be 32 for a 128 bit key or 48 for a 256 bit key
The number of diffusion rounds to use when generating the key stream
member.exception: Thrown if the seed is null or invalid, or rounds count is out of range

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Crypto.Prng.SP20Prng.#ctor(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initialize the class with a Seed; note: the same seed will produce the same random output
member.param: The Seed bytes used to initialize the digest counter; (min. length is key size + iv of 16 bytes)
The size of the cache of random bytes (must be more than 1024 to enable parallel processing)
The number of diffusion rounds to use when generating the key stream
member.exception: Thrown if the seed is null or invalid, or rounds count is out of range

member.name: T:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Crypto.Cipher.Asymmetric.Encrypt.NTRU.NTRUKeyGenerator
member.summary: This class implements the key pair generation of the NTRU Public Key Crypto System

example.description: Example of generating a key pair:

item.description: Randomly generate polynomials f and g in Df, Dg respectively.
Invert f in Rq to obtain fq, invert f in Rp to obtain fp, and check that g is invertible in Rq.
The public key h = p g fq (mod q). The private key is the pair (f, fp).
NTRU: A Ring Based Public Key Crypto SystemNTRU Crypto.
Optimizations for NTRUNTRU Optimizations.
Adaptive Key Recovery Attacks on NTRU-based Somewhat Homomorphic Encryption SchemesNTRU Adaptive.
Efficient Embedded Security Standards (EESS)NTRU EESS.
Practical lattice-based cryptography: NTRUEncrypt and NTRUSignNTRU Practical.
NTRU Cryptosystems Technical ReportNTRU Technical.
Inspired by the excellent java project NTRU Encrypt by Tim Buktu: Release 1.2, and the NTRUOpenSourceProject/ntru-crypto project provided by Security Innovation, Inc: Release 1.2.

summary.h3: TFX: An extended implementation of the Twofish encryption cipher.
summary.para: TFX is an implementation of the TwofishTwofish block cipher, extended to use a 512 bit key.

revisionHistory.revision: Secondary release; updates to layout and documentation

item.description: Valid Key sizes are 128, 192, 256 and 512 bits (16, 24, 32 and 64 bytes).
Block size is 16 bytes wide.
Valid Rounds assignments are 16, 18, 20, 22, 24, 26, 28, 30 and 32, default is 16.

remarks.para: TFX extends the original design allowing it to accept the longer key length (512 bits).

item.description: Twofish: A 128-Bit Block Cipher.
Inspired in part by the Bouncy Castle Java Release 1.51.

summary.h3: RDX: An extended implementation of the Rijndael encryption cipher.
summary.para: RDX is an implementation of the RijndaelRijndael encryption algorithm, extended to use a 512 bit key

revisionHistory.revision: Secondary release; updates to layout and documentation

item.description: Valid Key sizes are 128, 192, 256, and 512 bit.
Valid block sizes are 16 and 32 bytes wide.

remarks.para: RDX is an implementation of the RijndaelRijndael encryption algorithm, the same one used in the AESFips 197 standard. What has been done is to extend Rijndael so that it now accepts the longer key length (512 bits). The extended key length provides more security against attacks that attempt to brute force the key, and also adds eight more rounds of diffusion.

The increased number of rounds brings the total from 14 rounds with a 256 bit key, to 22 rounds with the 512 bit key size. These added passes through the rounds function further disperse the input through row and column transpositions, and XORs with a longer expanded key array.

item.description: AES Proposal: Rijndael.
Fips 197: Announcing the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES)
Inspired in part by the Mono: RijndaelManagedTransform class.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.MathContext.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary:
Constructs a new MathContext with the specified precision and with the rounding mode RoundingMode.HalfUp.
If the precision passed is zero, then this implies that the computations have to be performed exact, the rounding mode in this case is irrelevant.
member.param: The precision for the new MathContext

Constructs a new MathContext with the specified precision and with the specified rounding mode.
If the precision passed is zero, then this implies that the computations have to be performed exact, the rounding mode in this case is irrelevant.
member.param: The precision for the new MathContext
The rounding mode for the new MathContext
member.exception: Thrown if the Precision is less than zero

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.MathContext.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary:
Constructs a new MathContext from a string.
The string has to specify the precision and the rounding mode to be used and has to follow the following syntax: "Precision=<Precision> RoundingMode=<RoundingMode>" This is the same form as the one returned by the ToString method.
member.param: A string describing the precision and rounding mode for the new MathContext
member.exception: Thrown if the string is not in the correct format or if the Precision specified is < 0

member.summary: Returns the hash code for this MathContext instance
member.returns: Returns the hash code for this MathContext

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.MathContext.ToString
member.summary:
Returns the string representation for this MathContext instance
The string has the form "Precision=<Precision> RoundingMode=<RoundingMode>" where <Precision> is an integer describing the number of digits used for operations and <RoundingMode> is the string representation of the rounding mode.
member.returns: Returns a string representation for this MathContext instance

member.name: P:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.MathContext.Precision
member.summary:
Returns the precision.
The precision is the number of digits used for an operation.

remarks.para: Results are rounded to this precision. The precision is guaranteed to be non negative. If the precision is zero, then the computations have to be performed exact, results are not rounded in this case.

member.name: P:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.MathContext.RoundingMode
member.summary:
Returns the rounding mode.
The rounding mode is the strategy to be used to round results.

member.name: T:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.Elementary
member.summary:
Static library that provides the basic arithmetic mutable operations for BigInteger.
The operations provided are:
Addition
Subtraction
Comparison/>
In addition to this, some Inplace (mutable) methods are provided.

member.summary:
Compares two arrays. All elements are treated as unsigned integers.
The magnitude is the bit chain of elements in big-endian order.
member.returns: Returns 1 if A > B, -1 if A < B, 0 if A == B

Same as InplaceSubtract(BigInteger, BigInteger), but without the restriction of non-positive values

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.Elementary.InplaceAdd(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger,VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger)
member.summary:
Performs Op1 += Op2.
Op1 must have enough place to store the result (i.e. Op1.BitLength() >= Op2.BitLength()). Both should be positive (i.e. Op1 >= Op2).
member.param: The input minuend, and the output result

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.Elementary.InplaceAdd(System.Int32[],System.Int32,System.Int32)

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.Elementary.InplaceAdd(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Performs: Op1 += Addend.
The number must have a place to hold a possible carry.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.Elementary.InplaceSubtract(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger,VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger)
member.summary:
Performs Op1 -= Op2.
Op1 must have enough place to store the result (i.e. Op1.BitLength() >= Op2.BitLength()). Both should be positive (what implies that Op1 >= Op2).
member.param: The input minuend, and the output result

summary.h3: DGCPrng: An implementation of a Digest Counter based Random Number Generator.
summary.para: Uses a Digest Counter DRBG as outlined in NIST document: SP800-90ASP800-90A

item.description: Can be initialized with any digest.
Can use either a random seed generator for initialization, or a user supplied Seed array.
Numbers generated with the same seed will produce the same random output.
NIST SP800-90A: Appendix E1.
NIST SP800-90B: Recommendation for the Entropy Sources Used for Random Bit Generation.
NIST Fips 140-2: Security Requirments For Cryptographic Modules.
NIST SP800-22 1a: A Statistical Test Suite for Random and Pseudorandom Number Generators for Cryptographic Applications.
Security Bounds for the NIST Codebook-based: Deterministic Random Bit Generator.
Based on the Bouncy Castle Java Release 1.51 version.

member.summary: Initialize the class
member.param: The digest that powers the rng (default is Keccak512)
The Seed engine used to create the salt (default is CSPRsg)

Parallel block size is 64,000 bytes by default; but is configurable.
Salsa20 Specification.
Salsa20 Design.
Salsa20 Security.
Inspired in part by the Bouncy Castle Java Release 1.51.

summary.h3: THX: A Twofish Cipher extended with an HKDF powered Key Schedule.
summary.para: THX is an implementation of the TwofishTwofish block cipher combined with an HKDF powered Key Schedule.

revisionHistory.revision: Initial release using a fixed Digest key schedule generator
Secondary release using an assignable Digest in the HKDF engine
Added the IkmSize optional parameter to the constructor, and the DistributionCode property

item.description: HKDF Digest engine is definable through the Constructor parameter: KeyEngine.
Key Schedule is powered by a Hash based Key Derivation Function using a definable Digest.
Minimum key size is (IKm + Salt) (N * Digest State Size) + (Digest Hash Size) in bytes.
Valid block size is 16 bytes wide.
Valid Rounds assignments are 16, 18, 20, 22, 24, 26, 28, 30 and 32, default is 16.

remarks.para: The number of transformation rounds processed is also user definable; from the standard 16 rounds, to a full 32 rounds of transformation.

The key schedule in THX powered by an HKDFRFC 5869 generator, using a Digest HMACRFC 2104 (Hash based Message Authentication Code) as its random engine. This is one of the strongestFips 198-1 methods available for generating pseudo-random keying material, and far superior in entropy dispersion to Rijndael, or even the Twofish key schedule. HKDF uses up to three inputs; a nonce value called an information string, an Ikm (Input keying material), and a Salt value. The HMAC RFC 2104, recommends a key size equal to the digest output, in the case of SHA512, 64 bytes, anything larger gets passed through the hash function to get the required 512 bit key size. The Salt size is a minimum of the hash functions block size, with SHA-2 512 that is 128 bytes.

When using SHA-2 512, a minimum key size for RSM is 192 bytes, further blocks of salt can be added to the key so long as they align; ikm + (n * blocksize), ex. 192, 320, 448 bytes.. there is no upper maximum. This means that you can create keys as large as you like so long as it falls on these boundaries, this effectively eliminates brute force as a means of attack on the cipher, even in quantum terms.
The Digest that powers HKDF, can be any one of the Hash Digests implemented in the CEX library; BlakeBlake, KeccakKeccak, SHA-2Fips 180-4, or SkeinSkein. The default Digest Engine is SHA-2 512.

The legal key sizes are determined by a combination of the (Hash Size + a Multiplier * the Digest State Size); klen = h + (n * s), this will vary between Digest implementations. Correct key sizes can be determined at runtime using the property.

The number of diffusion rounds processed within the ciphers rounds function can also be defined; adding rounds creates a more diffused cipher output, making the resulting cipher-text more difficult to cryptanalyze. THX is capable of processing up to 32 rounds, that is twice the number of rounds used in a standard implementation of Twofish. Valid rounds assignments can be found in the static property.

summary.h3: SHX: A Serpent cipher extended with an HKDF powered Key Schedule.
summary.para: SHX is a SerpentSerpent implementation that uses an HKDF generator to expand the user supplied key into a working key integer array.

revisionHistory.revision: Initial release using a fixed Digest key schedule generator
Secondary release using an assignable Digest in the HKDF engine
Added the IkmSize optional parameter to the constructor, and the DistributionCode property

item.description: HKDF Digest engine is definable through the Constructor parameter: KeyEngine.
Key Schedule is powered by a Hash based Key Derivation Function using a definable Digest.
Minimum key size is (IKm + Salt) (N * Digest State Size) + (Digest Hash Size) in bytes.
Valid block size is 16 bytes wide.
Valid Rounds assignments are 32, 40, 48, 56, 64, 80, 96 and 128, default is 64.

remarks.para: It also takes a user defined number of rounds between 32 (the standard number of rounds), all the way up to 128 rounds in 8 round sets. A round count of 40 or 48 is more than sufficient, as theoretical attacks to date are only able to break up to 12 rounds; and would require an enormous amount of memory and processing power. The transform in SHX is identical to the Serpent implementation SPX, it process rounds by first moving the byte input array into 4 integers, then processing the rounds in a while loop. Each round consists of an XOR of each state word (Rn) with a key, an S-Box transformation of those words, and then a linear transformation. Each of the 8 S-Boxes are used in succession within a loop cycle. The final round XORs the last 4 keys with the state and shifts them back into the output byte array.

The key schedule in SHX powered by an HKDFRFC 5869 generator, using a Digest HMACRFC 2104 (Hash based Message Authentication Code) as its random engine. This is one of the strongestFips 198-1 methods available for generating pseudo-random keying material, and far superior in entropy dispersion to Rijndael, or even Serpents key schedule. HKDF uses up to three inputs; a nonce value called an information string, an Ikm (Input keying material), and a Salt value. The HMAC RFC 2104, recommends a key size equal to the digest output, in the case of SHA512, 64 bytes, anything larger gets passed through the hash function to get the required 512 bit key size. The Salt size is a minimum of the hash functions block size, with SHA-2 512 that is 128 bytes.

When using SHA-2 512, a minimum key size for RSM is 192 bytes, further blocks of salt can be added to the key so long as they align; ikm + (n * blocksize), ex. 192, 320, 448 bytes.. there is no upper maximum. This means that you can create keys as large as you like so long as it falls on these boundaries, this effectively eliminates brute force as a means of attack on the cipher, even in quantum terms.
The Digest that powers HKDF, can be any one of the Hash Digests implemented in the CEX library; BlakeBlake, KeccakKeccak, SHA-2Fips 180-4, or SkeinSkein. The default Digest Engine is SHA-2 512.

The legal key sizes are determined by a combination of the (Hash Size + a Multiplier * the Digest State Size); klen = h + (n * s), this will vary between Digest implementations. Correct key sizes can be determined at runtime using the property.

The number of diffusion rounds processed within the ciphers rounds function can also be defined; adding rounds creates a more diffused cipher output, making the resulting cipher-text more difficult to cryptanalyze. SHX is capable of processing up to 128 rounds, that is four times the number of rounds used in a standard implementation of Serpent. Valid rounds assignments can be found in the static property.

summary.h3: RHX: A Rijndael Cipher extended with an HKDF powered Key Schedule.
summary.para: RHX is a RijndaelRijndael implementation that uses an HKDF generator to expand the user supplied key into a working key integer array.

revisionHistory.revision: Initial release using a fixed Digest key schedule generator
Secondary release using an assignable Digest in the HKDF engine
Added the IkmSize optional parameter to the constructor, and the DistributionCode property

remarks.para: The key schedule in RHX is the defining difference between this and a standard version of RijndaelRijndael; instead of using a simple inline function to expand the user supplied key into a larger working array, it uses a hash based pseudo-random generator to create the working key.

item.description: HKDF Digest engine is definable through the Constructor parameter: KeyEngine.
Key Schedule is powered by a Hash based Key Derivation Function using a definable Digest.
Minimum key size is (IKm + Salt) (N * Digest State Size) + (Digest Hash Size) in bytes.
Valid block sizes are 16 and 32 byte wide.
Valid Rounds are 10 to 38, default is 22.

remarks.para: HKDFRFC 5869 is a key derivation function that uses a Digest HMACRFC 2104 (Hash based Message Authentication Code) as its random engine. This is one of the strongestFips 198-1 methods available for generating pseudo-random keying material, and far superior in entropy dispersion to Rijndael, or even Serpents key schedule. HKDF uses up to three inputs; a nonce value called an information string, an Ikm (Input keying material), and a Salt value. The HMAC RFC 2104, recommends a key size equal to the digest output, in the case of SHA512, 64 bytes, anything larger gets passed through the hash function to get the required 512 bit key size. The Salt size is a minimum of the hash functions block size, with SHA-2 512 that is 128 bytes.

When using SHA-2 512, a minimum key size for RHX is 192 bytes, further blocks of salt can be added to the key so long as they align; ikm + (n * blocksize), ex. 192, 320, 448 bytes.. there is no upper maximum. This means that you can create keys as large as you like so long as it falls on these boundaries, this effectively eliminates brute force as a means of attack on the cipher, even in post-quantum terms.
The Digest that powers HKDF, can be any one of the Hash Digests implemented in the CEX library; BlakeBlake, KeccakKeccak, SHA-2Fips 180-4, or SkeinSkein. The default Digest Engine is SHA-2 512.

The legal key sizes are determined by a combination of the (Hash Size + a Multiplier * the Digest State Size); klen = h + (n * s), this will vary between Digest implementations. Correct key sizes can be determined at runtime using the property.

The number of diffusion rounds processed within the ciphers rounds function can also be defined; adding rounds creates a more diffused cipher output, making the resulting cipher-text more difficult to cryptanalyze. RHX is capable of processing up to 38 rounds, that is twenty-four rounds more than the fourteen rounds used in an implementation of AES-256. Valid rounds assignments can be found in the static property.

item.description: NIST: AES Fips 197.
HMAC: RFC 2104.
HKDF: RFC 5869.
NIST: SP800-90B.
Inspired in part by the Mono: RijndaelManagedTransform class, and the Bouncy Castle Java Release 1.51.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.Conversion.BigInteger2Double(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger)
member.summary:
Returns this BigInteger as an double value.
If this is too big to be represented as an double, then Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY or Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY} is returned.
member.returns: Returns a BigInteger as a double value
member.remarks: Note, that not all integers x in the range [-Double.MAX_VALUE, Double.MAX_VALUE] can be represented as a double. The double representation has a mantissa of length 53. For example, 2^53+1 = 9007199254740993 is returned as double 9007199254740992.0.

member.summary:
Returns a string containing a string representation of this BigInteger with base radix.
If Radix < CharHelper.MIN_RADIX} or Radix > CharHelper.MAX_RADIX then a decimal representation is returned. The CharHelpers of the string representation are generated with method CharHelper.forDigit.
member.param: Base to be used for the string representation
member.returns: Returns a string representation of this with radix 10

summary.h3: An implementation of the Cubic Congruential Generator II random number generator: CCG
summary.para: Implements CCG as defined in the NIST document: SP800-22 1aSP800-22A, Section D.4

item.description: NIST SP800-22 1a, Section D.3: A Statistical Test Suite for Random and Pseudorandom Number Generators for Cryptographic Applications.
NIST SP800-90B: SP800-90BRecommendation for the Entropy Sources Used for Random Bit Generation.
NIST Fips 140-2: Fips 140-2Security Requirments For Cryptographic Modules.
RFC 4086: RFC 4086Randomness Requirements for Security.
This code based on the excellent Java version by Zur Aougav: CubicResiduePrng class.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.Primality.NextProbablePrime(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger)
member.summary:
It uses the sieve of Eratosthenes to discard several composite numbers in some appropriate range (at the moment [this, this + 1024]).
After this process it applies the Miller-Rabin test to the numbers that were not discarded in the sieve.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.Primality.ConsBigInteger(System.Int32,System.Int32,VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Crypto.Prng.SecureRandom)
member.summary: A random number is generated until a probable prime number is found

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.Primality.IsProbablePrime(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Tests whether this BigInteger is probably prime.
If true is returned, then this is prime with a probability beyond (1-1/2^certainty). If false is returned, then this is definitely composite. If the argument Certainty <= 0, then this method returns true.
member.returns: Returns true, if this is probably prime, false otherwise

summary.h3: This class represents immutable integer numbers of arbitrary length
summary.para: All operations behave as if BigIntegers were represented in two's-complement notation. BigInteger provides operations for modular arithmetic, GCD calculation, primality testing, prime generation, bit manipulation, and a few other miscellaneous operations.

example.code: BigInteger p = BigInteger.ProbablePrime(BitLength, new SecureRandom());

remarks.para: Semantics of arithmetic operations exactly mimic those of Java's integer arithmetic operators, as defined in The Java Language Specification. For example, division by zero throws an ArithmeticException, and division of a negative by a positive yields a negative (or zero) remainder. All of the details in the Spec concerning overflow are ignored, as BigIntegers are made as large as necessary to accommodate the results of an operation.
Semantics of shift operations allow for negative shift distances. A right-shift with a negative shift distance results in a left shift, and vice-versa.
The binary operators (And, Or, Xor) implicitly perform sign extension on the shorter of the two operands prior to performing the operation.

Modular arithmetic operations are provided to compute residues, perform exponentiation, and compute multiplicative inverses. These methods always return a non-negative result, between 0 and (Modulus - 1), inclusive.

Bit operations operate on a single bit of the two's-complement representation of their operand. If necessary, the operand is sign-extended so that it contains the designated bit. None of the single-bit operations can produce a BigInteger with a different sign from the BigInteger being operated on, as they affect only a single bit, and the "infinite word size" abstraction provided by this class ensures that there are infinitely many "virtual sign bits" preceding each BigInteger.
Large numbers are typically used in security applications and therefore BigIntegers offer dedicated functionality like the generation of large prime numbers or the computation of modular inverse.

Since the class was modeled to offer all the functionality as the Integer class does, it provides even methods that operate bitwise on a two's complement representation of large integers. Note however that the implementations favors an internal representation where magnitude and sign are treated separately. Hence such operations are inefficient and should be discouraged. In simple words: Do NOT implement any bit fields based on BigInteger.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger.#ctor(System.Byte[])
member.summary:
Constructs a new BigInteger from the given two's complement representation.
The most significant byte is the entry at index 0. The most significant bit of this entry determines the sign of the new BigInteger instance. The given array must not be empty.
member.param: Two's complement representation of the new BigInteger

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Byte[])
member.summary:
Constructs a new BigInteger instance with the given sign and the given magnitude.
The sign is given as an integer (-1 for negative, 0 for zero, 1 for positive). The magnitude is specified as a byte array. The most significant byte is the entry at index 0.
member.param: Sign of the new BigInteger (-1 for negative, 0 for zero, 1 for positive)
Magnitude of the new BigInteger with the most significant byte first
member.exception: Thrown if an invalid Signum or Magnitude is passed

member.exception: Thrown if NumBits > 0

member.returns: Returns 1 if this > Value, -1 if this < Value, 0 if this == Value

member.summary:
Tests whether this BigInteger is probably prime.
If true is returned, then this is prime with a probability beyond (1-1/2^certainty). If false is returned, then this is definitely composite. If the argument Certainty <= 0, then this method returns true.
member.returns: Returns true, if this is probably prime, false otherwise

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger.Mod(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger)
member.summary:
Returns a new BigInteger whose value is this Mod M.
The modulus M must be positive. The result is guaranteed to be in the interval (0, M) (0 inclusive, m exclusive). The behavior of this function is not equivalent to the behavior of the % operator defined for the built-in int's.
member.exception: Thrown if M == null or M < 0

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger.ModPow(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger,VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger)
member.summary:
Returns a new BigInteger whose value is this^Exponent Mod M.
The modulus M must be positive. The result is guaranteed to be in the interval (0, M) (0 inclusive, m exclusive). If the Exponent is negative, then this.ModInverse(M)^(-Exponent) Mod M) is computed. The inverse of this only exists if this is relatively prime to M, otherwise an exception is thrown.
member.exception: Thrown if M < 0 or if Exponent<0 and this is not relatively prime to M

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger.ModInverse(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger)
member.summary:
Returns a new BigInteger whose value is 1/this Mod M.
The modulus M must be positive. The result is guaranteed to be in the interval (0, M) (0 inclusive, M exclusive). If this is not relatively prime to M, then an exception is thrown.
member.exception: Thrown if M < 0 or, if this is not relatively prime to code M

member.summary: Returns a new BigInteger whose value is this * Value

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger.SetBit(System.Int32)
member.summary:
Returns a new BigInteger which has the same binary representation as this but with the bit at position N set.
The result is equivalent to this | 2^n.
member.param: Position where the bit in this has to be set

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger.ShiftLeft(System.Int32)
member.summary:
Returns a new BigInteger whose value is this << N.
The result is equivalent to this * 2^n if n >= 0. The shift distance may be negative which means that this is shifted right. The result then corresponds to Floor(this / 2^(-n)).
member.returns: Returns this << N if n >= 0, this >> (-N) otherwise

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger.ShiftRight(System.Int32)
member.summary:
Returns a new BigInteger whose value is this >> N.
For negative arguments, the result is also negative. The shift distance may be negative which means that this is shifted left.
member.returns: this >> N, if N >= 0; this << (-n) otherwise

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger.Signum
member.summary: Returns the sign of this BigInteger
member.returns: Returns -1 if this < 0, 0 if this == 0, 1 if this > 0

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger.Subtract(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger)
member.summary: Returns a new BigInteger whose value is this - val
member.param: Value to be subtracted from this

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger.TestBit(System.Int32)
member.summary:
Tests whether the bit at position N in this is set.
The result is equivalent to this & (2^n) != 0.
member.param: Position where the bit in this has to be inspected.
member.remarks: Implementation Note: Usage of this method is not recommended as the current implementation is not efficient.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger.ToDouble
member.summary:
Returns this BigInteger as an double value.
If this is too big to be represented as an double, then Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY or Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY} is returned.
member.returns: Returns this BigInteger as a double value
member.remarks:
Note, that not all integers x in the range [-Double.MAX_VALUE, Double.MAX_VALUE] can be represented as a double.
The double representation has a mantissa of length 53. For example, 2^53+1 = 9007199254740993 is returned as double 9007199254740992.0.

The modulus M must be positive. The result is guaranteed to be in the interval (0, M) (0 inclusive, m exclusive). The behavior of this function is not equivalent to the behavior of the % operator defined for the built-in int's.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger.op_RightShift(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Returns a new BigInteger whose value is this >> N
For negative arguments, the result is also negative. The shift distance may be negative which means that this is shifted left.
member.returns: Returns X >> N, if N >= 0; X << (-N) otherwise

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger.op_LeftShift(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Returns a new BigInteger whose value is this << N.
The result is equivalent to this * 2^n if n >= 0. The shift distance may be negative which means that this is shifted right. The result then corresponds to Floor(this / 2^(-n)).
member.returns: Returns X << N if N >= 0, X >> (-N) otherwise

member.name: P:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger.BitCount
member.summary:
Returns the number of bits in the binary representation of this which differ from the sign bit.
Use BitLength(0) if you want to know the length of the binary value in bits. If this is positive the result is equivalent to the number of bits set in the binary representation of this. If this is negative the result is equivalent to the number of bits set in the binary representation of -this - 1.

member.name: P:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger.BitLength
member.summary:
Returns the length of the value's two's complement representation without leading zeros for positive numbers / without leading ones for negative values.
The two's complement representation of this will be at least BitLength() + 1 bits long. The value will fit into an int if bitLength() < 32 or into a long if bitLength() < 64.

member.name: P:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger.LowestSetBit
member.summary:
Returns the position of the lowest set bit in the two's complement representation of this BigInteger.
If all bits are zero (this=0) then -1 is returned as result.

summary.h3: SHA256 Hash based Message Authentication Code Wrapper using SHA-2 256.
summary.para: A SHA512 HMAC as outlined in the NIST document: Fips 198-1Fips 198-1

item.description: Key size should be equal to digest output sizeRFC 2104; 32 bytes, (256 bits).
Block size is 64 bytes, (512 bits).
Digest size is 32 bytes, (256 bits).
The Constructors DisposeEngine parameter determines if Digest engine is destroyed when is called on this class; default is true.

list.item: The method wraps the and DoFinal methods./>

item.description: The method resets the internal state.
RFC 2104: HMAC: Keyed-Hashing for Message Authentication.
NIST Fips 198-1: The Keyed-Hash Message Authentication Code (HMAC).
NIST Fips 180-4: Secure Hash Standard (SHS).
Based on the Bouncy Castle Java Release 1.51 version.

summary.h3: A helper class for generating cryptographically strong keying material.
summary.para: Generates an array or a populated KeyParams class, using a definable Digest(Prng) dual stage generator.

example.description: Create an array of pseudo random keying material:

revisionHistory.revision: Assignable digests and Prng parameters added

item.description: SHA-2 Generates key material using a two stage Hmac_k(Prng()) process.
BlakeBlake, KeccakKeccak, and SkeinSkein also use a two stage generation method; Hash(Prng()).
Prng can be any of the generators.
Hash can be any of the digests.
Default Prng is CSPRngRNGCryptoServiceProvider, default digest is SHA512.
Resources are disposed of automatically.

summary.para: Initializes the class with default generators; SHA-2 512, and RNGCryptoServiceProvider

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Crypto.Cipher.Asymmetric.Encrypt.NTRU.Polynomial.IntegerPolynomial.Resultant
member.summary: Resultant of this polynomial with x^n-1 using a probabilistic algorithm.

remarks.para: Unlike EESS, this implementation does not compute all resultants modulo primes such that their product exceeds the maximum possible resultant, but rather stops when NUM_EQUAL_RESULTANTS consecutive modular resultants are equal. This means the return value may be incorrect. Experiments show this happens in about 1 out of 100 cases when N=439 and NUM_EQUAL_RESULTANTS=2, so the likelyhood of leaving the loop too early is (1/100)^(NUM_EQUAL_RESULTANTS-1).
Because of the above, callers must verify the output and try a different polynomial if necessary.

member.returns: Returns (rho, res) satisfying res = rho*this + t*(x^n-1) for some integer t.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Crypto.Cipher.Asymmetric.Encrypt.NTRU.Polynomial.IntegerPolynomial.Rotate1
member.summary: Multiplication by X in Z[X]/Z[X^n-1].

member.summary: Subtracts another polynomial which must not have more coefficients than this polynomial.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Crypto.Cipher.Asymmetric.Encrypt.NTRU.Polynomial.IntegerPolynomial.Resultant(System.Int32)
member.summary: Resultant of this polynomial with x^n-1 mod p.
member.returns: Returns (rho, res) satisfying res = rho*this + t*(x^n-1) mod p for some integer t.

coeffs[2*i] and coeffs[2*i+1] must not both equal -1 for any integer i, so this method is only safe to use with polynomials produced by fromBinary3Sves().

member.name: T:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Crypto.Cipher.Asymmetric.Encrypt.NTRU.NTRUEncrypt
member.summary: An NTRU asymmetric cipher implementation

example.description: Example of encryption/decryption of plain text:

item.description: Randomly select a small polynomial r Dr.
Calculate the ciphertext e as e r h+m (mod q).
Calculate a center(f e), where the centering operation center reduces its input into the interval [A,A+q1].
Recover m by calculating m fp a (mod p).
NTRU: A Ring Based Public Key Crypto SystemNTRU Crypto.
Optimizations for NTRUNTRU Optimizations.
Adaptive Key Recovery Attacks on NTRU-based Somewhat Homomorphic Encryption SchemesNTRU Adaptive.
Efficient Embedded Security Standards (EESS)NTRU EESS.
Practical lattice-based cryptography: NTRUEncrypt and NTRUSignNTRU Practical.
NTRU Cryptosystems Technical ReportNTRU Technical.
Inspired by the excellent java project NTRU Encrypt by Tim Buktu: Release 1.2, and the NTRUOpenSourceProject/ntru-crypto project provided by Security Innovation, Inc: Release 1.2.

summary.h3: CTRDrbg: An implementation of a Encryption Counter based Deterministic Random Byte Generator.
summary.para: A Block Cipher Counter DRBG as outlined in NIST document: SP800-90ASP800-90B

item.description: Can be initialized with any block cipher.
Parallelized by default on a multi processer system when an input byte array of bytes or larger is used.
Parallelization can be disabled using the property.
The Constructors DisposeEngine parameter determines if Cipher engine is destroyed when is called on this class; default is true.
Combination of [Salt, Ikm, Nonce] must be: cipher key size + cipher block size in length.
Nonce and Ikm are optional, (but recommended).
NIST SP800-90B: Recommendation for the Entropy Sources Used for Random Bit Generation.
NIST Fips 140-2: Security Requirments For Cryptographic Modules.
NIST SP800-22 1a: A Statistical Test Suite for Random and Pseudorandom Number Generators for Cryptographic Applications.
Security Bounds for the NIST Codebook-based: Deterministic Random Bit Generator.

summary.h3: TSM: An implementation based on the Twofish and Serpent Merged block ciphers, extended with an HKDF powered Key Schedule.
summary.para: TSM is TwofishTwofish and SerpentSerpent ciphers, merged within the rounds function.

revisionHistory.revision: Initial release using a fixed Digest key schedule generator
Secondary release using an assignable Digest in the HKDF engine
Added the IkmSize optional parameter to the constructor, and the DistributionCode property

item.description: HKDF Digest engine is definable through the Constructor parameter: KeyEngine.
Key Schedule is powered by a Hash based Key Derivation Function using a definable Digest.
Minimum key size is (IKm + Salt) (N * Digest State Size) + (Digest Hash Size) in bytes.
Valid block size is 16 bytes wide.
Valid Rounds assignments are 16, 24, and 32, default is 16.

remarks.para: The transform combines the two ciphers within the rounds function processing loop. In the rounds functions, a round of Twofish is processed; the permuted product of that transformation is then transformed again by a round of Serpent. This alternating of state transformations between two very strong cryptographic primitives, both creates a highly diffused output, and creates a cipher that is very resistant to cryptanalysis.

The key schedule in TSM powered by an HKDFRFC 5869 generator, using a Digest HMACRFC 2104 (Hash based Message Authentication Code) as its random engine. This is one of the strongestFips 198-1 methods available for generating pseudo-random keying material, and far superior in entropy dispersion to Rijndael, or even Serpents key schedule. HKDF uses up to three inputs; a nonce value called an information string, an Ikm (Input keying material), and a Salt value. The HMAC RFC 2104, recommends a key size equal to the digest output, in the case of SHA512, 64 bytes, anything larger gets passed through the hash function to get the required 512 bit key size. The Salt size is a minimum of the hash functions block size, with SHA-2 512 that is 128 bytes.

When using SHA-2 512, a minimum key size for RSM is 192 bytes, further blocks of salt can be added to the key so long as they align; ikm + (n * blocksize), ex. 192, 320, 448 bytes.. there is no upper maximum. This means that you can create keys as large as you like so long as it falls on these boundaries, this effectively eliminates brute force as a means of attack on the cipher, even in quantum terms.
The Digest that powers HKDF, can be any one of the Hash Digests implemented in the CEX library; BlakeBlake, KeccakKeccak, SHA-2Fips 180-4, or SkeinSkein. The default Digest Engine is SHA-2 512.

The legal key sizes are determined by a combination of the (Hash Size + a Multiplier * the Digest State Size); klen = h + (n * s), this will vary between Digest implementations. Correct key sizes can be determined at runtime using the property.

The number of diffusion rounds processed within the ciphers rounds function can also be defined; adding rounds creates a more diffused cipher output, making the resulting cipher-text more difficult to cryptanalyze. TSM is capable of processing up to 32 rounds, that is twice the number of rounds used in a standard implementation of Twofish. Valid rounds assignments can be found in the static property.

item.description: Twofish: Specification.
Serpent: Specification.
HMAC: RFC 2104.
NIST: Fips 198.1.
HKDF: RFC 5869.
NIST: SP800-90B.
Inspired in part by the Bouncy Castle Java Release 1.51.

member.summary:
Get/Set: Sets the Info value in the HKDF initialization parameters.
Must be set before is called. Changing this code will create a unique distribution of the cipher. Code can be either a zero byte array, or a multiple of the HKDF digest engines return size.
member.exception: Thrown if an invalid distribution code is used

member.name: P:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Crypto.Cipher.Symmetric.Block.TSM.IkmSize
member.summary:
Get/Set: Specify the size of the HMAC key; extracted from the cipher key.
This property can only be changed before the Initialize function is called.
Default is the digest return size; can only be a multiple of that length. Maximum size is the digests underlying block size; if the key is longer than this, the size will default to the block size.

summary.h3: CTRPrng: An implementation of a Encryption Counter based Deterministic Random Number Generator.
summary.para: A Block Cipher Counter DRBG as outlined in NIST document: SP800-90ASP800-90B

item.description: Can be initialized with any block cipher.
Can use either a random seed generator for initialization, or a user supplied Seed array.
Numbers generated with the same seed will produce the same random output.

NIST Fips 140-2: Security Requirments For Cryptographic Modules.
NIST SP800-22 1a: A Statistical Test Suite for Random and Pseudorandom Number Generators for Cryptographic Applications.
Security Bounds for the NIST Codebook-based: Deterministic Random Bit Generator.

summary.h3: RSM: An implementation based on the Rijndael and Serpent Merged block ciphers, extended with an HKDF powered Key Schedule.
summary.para: RSM is the RijndaelRijndael and SerpentSerpent ciphers, merged within the rounds function.

revisionHistory.revision: Initial release using a fixed Digest key schedule generator
Secondary release using an assignable Digest in the HKDF engine
Added the IkmSize optional parameter to the constructor, and the DistributionCode property

item.description: The HKDF Digest engine is definable through the Constructor parameter: KeyEngine.
Key Schedule is powered by a Hash based Key Derivation Function using a definable Digest.
Minimum key size is (IKm + Salt) (N * Digest State Size) + (Digest Hash Size) in bytes.
Valid block sizes are 16 and 32 byte wide.
Valid Rounds assignments are 10, 18, 26, 34 and 42, default is 18.

remarks.para: The transform combines the two ciphers within the rounds function processing loop. In the Transform functions rounds loop, a round of Serpent is processed; the permuted product of that transformation is then transformed again by a full round of Rijndael. This alternating of state transformations between two very strong cryptographic primitives, both creates a highly diffused output, and a cipher that is very resistant to differential cryptanalysis.

The key schedule in RSM powered by an HKDFRFC 5869 generator, using a Digest HMACRFC 2104 (Hash based Message Authentication Code) as its random engine. This is one of the strongestFips 198-1 methods available for generating pseudo-random keying material, and far superior in entropy dispersion to Rijndael, or even Serpents key schedule. HKDF uses up to three inputs; a nonce value called an information string, an Ikm (Input keying material), and a Salt value. The HMAC RFC 2104, recommends a key size equal to the digest output, in the case of SHA512, 64 bytes, anything larger gets passed through the hash function to get the required 512 bit key size. The Salt size is a minimum of the hash functions block size, with SHA-2 512 that is 128 bytes.

When using SHA-2 512, a minimum key size for RSM is 192 bytes, further blocks of salt can be added to the key so long as they align; ikm + (n * blocksize), ex. 192, 320, 448 bytes.. there is no upper maximum. This means that you can create keys as large as you like so long as it falls on these boundaries, this effectively eliminates brute force as a means of attack on the cipher, even in quantum terms.
The Digest that powers HKDF, can be any one of the Hash Digests implemented in the CEX library; BlakeBlake, KeccakKeccak, SHA-2Fips 180-4, or SkeinSkein. The default Digest Engine is SHA-2 512.

The legal key sizes are determined by a combination of the (Hash Size + a Multiplier * the Digest State Size); klen = h + (n * s), this will vary between Digest implementations. Correct key sizes can be determined at runtime using the property.

The number of diffusion rounds processed within the ciphers rounds function can also be defined; adding rounds creates a more diffused cipher output, making the resulting cipher-text more difficult to cryptanalyze. RSM is capable of processing up to 42 rounds, that is three times the number of rounds used in an implementation of AES-256. Valid rounds assignments can be found in the static property.

item.description: NIST: AES Fips 197.
Serpent: Specification.
HMAC: RFC 2104.
HKDF: RFC 5869.
NIST: SP800-90B.
Inspired in part by the Mono: RijndaelManagedTransform class, and the Bouncy Castle Java Release 1.51.

This property can only be changed before the Initialize function is called.

member.name: T:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal

summary.h3: This class represents immutable arbitrary precision decimal numbers
summary.para: A BigDecimal consists of an arbitrary precision integer unscaled valueand a 32-bit integer scale. If zero or positive, the scale is the number of digits to the right of the decimal point. If negative, the unscaled value of the number is multiplied by ten to the power of the negation of the scale. The value of the number represented by the BigDecimal is therefore (unscaledValue times; 10 pow -scale).

example.code: BigDecimal p = BigDecimal(bigInt);

member.remarks:
The BigDecimal class provides operations for arithmetic, scale manipulation, rounding, comparison, hashing, and format conversion. The ToString() method provides a canonical representation of a BigDecimal.
The BigDecimal class gives its user complete control over rounding behavior. If no rounding mode is specified and the exact result cannot be represented, an exception is thrown; otherwise, calculations can be carried out to a chosen precision and rounding mode by supplying an appropriate MathContext object to the operation. In either case, eight rounding modes are provided for the control of rounding. Using the integer fields in this class (such as HalfUp) to represent rounding mode is largely obsolete; the enumeration values of the RoundingMode enum, (such as HalfUp) should be used instead.
When a MathContext object is supplied with a precision setting of 0 (for example, Unnecessary), arithmetic operations are exact, as are the arithmetic methods which take no MathContext object. As a corollary of computing the exact result, the rounding mode setting of a MathContext object with a precision setting of 0 is not used and thus irrelevant. In the case of divide, the exact quotient could have an infinitely long decimal expansion; for example, 1 divided by 3. If the quotient has a nonterminating decimal expansion and the operation is specified to return an exact result, an ArithmeticException is thrown. Otherwise, the exact result of the division is returned, as done for other operations.
When the precision setting is not 0, the rules of BigDecimal arithmetic are broadly compatible with selected modes of operation of the arithmetic defined in ANSI X3.274-1996 and ANSI X3.274-1996/AM 1-2000 (section 7.4). Unlike those standards, BigDecimal includes many rounding modes. Any conflicts between these ANSI standards and the BigDecimal specification are resolved in favor of BigDecimal.
Since the same numerical value can have different representations (with different scales), the rules of arithmetic and rounding must specify both the numerical result and the scale used in the result's representation.
In general the rounding modes and precision setting determine how operations return results with a limited number of digits when the exact result has more digits (perhaps infinitely many in the case of division) than the number of digits returned.
First, the total number of digits to return is specified by the MathContext's Precision} setting; this determines the result's Precision. The digit count starts from the leftmost nonzero digit of the exact result. The rounding mode determines how any discarded trailing digits affect the returned result.
For all arithmetic operators , the operation is carried out as though an exact intermediate result were first calculated and then rounded to the number of digits specified by the precision setting (if necessary), using the selected rounding mode. If the exact result is not returned, some digit positions of the exact result are discarded. When rounding increases the magnitude of the returned result, it is possible for a new digit position to be created by a carry propagating to a leading "9" digit. For example, rounding the value 999.9 to three digits rounding up would be numerically equal to one thousand, represented as 100 times 10 pow 1. In such cases, the new "1" is the leading digit position of the returned result.
Besides a logical exact result, each arithmetic operation has a preferred scale for representing a result. The preferred scale for each operation is listed in the table below.
Preferred Scales for Results of Arithmetic Operations
Operation: Preferred Scale of Result
Add: Max(Addend.Scale(), Augend.Scale())
Subtract: Max(Minuend.Scale(), Subtrahend.Scale())
Multiply: Multiplier.Scale() + Multiplicand.Scale()
Divide: Dividend.Scale() - Divisor.Scale()
These scales are the ones used by the methods which return exact arithmetic results; except that an exact divide may have to use a larger scale since the exact result may have more digits. For example, 1/32 is 0.03125.
Before rounding, the scale of the logical exact intermediate result is the preferred scale for that operation. If the exact numerical result cannot be represented in Precision digits, rounding selects the set of digits to return and the scale of the result is reduced from the scale of the intermediate result to the least scale which can represent the Precision digits actually returned. If the exact result can be represented with at most Precision digits, the representation of the result with the scale closest to the preferred scale is returned. In particular, an exactly representable quotient may be represented in fewer than Precision digits by removing trailing zeros and decreasing the scale. For example, rounding to three digits using the Floor rounding mode.
Note that for add, subtract, and multiply, the reduction in scale will equal the number of digit positions of the exact result which are discarded. If the rounding causes a carry propagation to create a new high-order digit position, an additional digit of the result is discarded than when no new digit position is created.
Other methods may have slightly different rounding semantics. For example, the result of the Pow method using the Pow(int, MathContext) specified algorithm can occasionally differ from the rounded mathematical result by more than one unit in the last place, one Ulp.
Two types of operations are provided for manipulating the scale of a BigDecimal: scaling/rounding operations and decimal point motion operations. Scaling/rounding operations SetScale and Round}) return a BigDecimal whose value is approximately (or exactly) equal to that of the operand, but whose scale or precision is the specified value; that is, they increase or decrease the precision of the stored number with minimal effect on its value. Decimal point motion operations (MovePointLeft and MovePointRight) return a BigDecimal created from the operand by moving the decimal point a specified distance in the specified direction.
Each BigDecimal instance is represented with a unscaled arbitrary precision mantissa (the unscaled value) and a scale.
The value of the "BigDecimal is 10^(-). Since the ToString() method is overriden by this class and it changes the state of the object causing Heisenbugs for debuggability we add the attribute DebuggerDisplay that points to a method that doesn't change it.

member.summary:
Constructs a new instance from the 64bit double value.
The constructed big decimal is equivalent to the given double.
member.param: The double value to be converted to a instance
member.remarks:
For example, new BigDecimal(0.1) is equal to 0.1000000000000000055511151231257827021181583404541015625. This happens as 0.1 cannot be represented exactly in binary.
To generate a big decimal instance which is equivalent to 0.1 use the constructor.
member.exception: Thown if is infinity or not a number.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.CompareTo(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal)
member.summary:
Compares this BigDecimal with Value.
Returns one of the three values 1, 0, or -1. The method behaves as if Subtract(Value) is computed. If this difference is > 0 then 1 is returned, if the difference is < 0 then -1 is returned, and if the difference is 0 then 0 is returned. This means, that if two decimal instances are compared which are equal in value but differ in scale, then these two instances are considered as equal.
member.param: Value to be compared with this
member.returns: ReturnS 1 if this > Value, -1 if this < Value, 0 if this == Value

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.Divide(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal)
member.summary:
Returns a new BigDecimal whose value is this / divisor.
The scale of the result is the difference of the scales of this and Divisor. If the exact result requires more digits, then the scale is adjusted accordingly. For example, 1/128 = 0.0078125 which has a scale of 7 and precision 5.
member.param: Value by which this is divided
member.exception: Thrown if Divisor == 0 or the result cannot be represented exactly.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.MovePointLeft(System.Int32)
member.summary:
Returns a new BigDecimal instance where the decimal point has been moved N places to the left.
If N < 0 then the decimal point is moved -N places to the right. The result is obtained by changing its scale. If the scale of the result becomes negative, then its precision is increased such that the scale is zero. Note, that MovePointLeft(0) returns a result which is mathematically equivalent, but which has scale >= 0.
member.param: Number of places the decimal point has to be moved

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.MovePointRight(System.Int32)
member.summary:
Returns a new BigDecimal instance where the decimal point has been moved N places to the right.
If N < 0 then the decimal point is moved -N places to the left. The result is obtained by changing its scale. If the scale of the result becomes negative, then its precision is increased such that the scale is zero. Note, that MovePointRight(0) returns a result which is mathematically equivalent, but which has scale >= 0.
member.param: Number of placed the decimal point has to be moved

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.Round(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.MathContext)
member.summary:
Returns a new BigDecimal whose value is this, rounded according to the passed context.
If Context.Precision = 0, then no rounding is performed. If Context.Precision and Context.RoundingMode == UNNECESSARY, then an ArithmeticException is thrown if the result cannot be represented exactly within the given precision.
member.param: Rounding mode and precision for the result of this operation
member.returns: This rounded according to the passed context

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.ScaleByPowerOfTen(System.Int32)
member.summary:
Returns a new BigDecimal whose value is this 10^ N.
The scale of the result is Scale() - N. The precision of the result is the precision of this. This method has the same effect as MovePointRight, except that the precision is not changed.
member.param: Number of places the decimal point has to be moved

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.SetScale(System.Int32)
member.summary:
Returns a new BigDecimal instance with the specified scale.
If the new scale is greater than the old scale, then additional zeros are added to the unscaled value. If the new scale is smaller than the old scale, then trailing zeros are removed. If the trailing digits are not zeros then an ArithmeticException is thrown. If no exception is thrown, then the following equation holds: x.SetScale(s).CompareTo(x) == 0.
member.returns: A new BigDecimal instance with the specified scale.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.SetScale(System.Int32,VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.RoundingModes)
member.summary:
Returns a new BigDecimal instance with the specified scale.
If the new scale is greater than the old scale, then additional zeros are added to the unscaled value. If the new scale is smaller than the old scale, then trailing digits are removed. In this case no rounding is necessary. If these trailing digits are not zero, then the remaining unscaled value has to be rounded. For this rounding operation the specified rounding mode is used.
member.param: Rounding mode to be used to round the result
member.returns: A new BigDecimal instance with the specified scale

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.SetScale(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Returns a new BigDecimal instance with the specified scale.
If the new scale is greater than the old scale, then additional zeros are added to the unscaled value. In this case no rounding is necessary. If the new scale is smaller than the old scale, then trailing digits are removed. If these trailing digits are not zero, then the remaining unscaled value has to be rounded. For this rounding operation the specified rounding mode is used.
member.param: Rounding mode to be used to round the result
member.returns: A new BigDecimal instance with the specified scale
member.exception: Thrown if RoundMode is not a valid rounding mode

If the unscaled value of this has n trailing zeros, then the scale and the precision of the result has been reduced by n.
member.returns: A new BigDecimal instance equivalent to this where the trailing zeros of the unscaled value have been removed

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.ToBigInteger
member.summary:
Returns this BigDecimal as a big integer instance.
A fractional part is discarded.
member.returns: Returns this BigDecimal as a big integer instance

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.ToBigIntegerExact
member.summary:
Returns this BigDecimal as a big integer instance if it has no fractional part.
If this BigDecimal has a fractional part, i.e. if rounding would be necessary, an ArithmeticException is thrown.
member.returns: this BigDecimal as a big integer value
member.exception: Thrown if rounding is necessary

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.ToByteExact
member.summary:
Returns this BigDecimal as a byte value if it has no fractional part and if its value fits to the byte range ([-128..127]).
If these conditions are not met, an ArithmeticException is thrown.
member.returns: Returns this BigDecimal as a byte value

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.ToDouble
member.summary:
Returns this BigDecimal as a double value.
If this is too big to be represented as an float, then Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY or Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY is returned.
member.returns: Returns this BigDecimal as a double value

remarks.para: Note, that if the unscaled value has more than 53 significant digits, then this decimal cannot be represented exactly in a double variable. In this case the result is rounded. For example, if the instance x1 = new BigDecimal("0.1") cannot be represented exactly as a double, and thus x1.Equals(new BigDecimal(x1.ToDouble()) returns false for this case. Similarly, if the instance new BigDecimal(9007199254740993L)c> is converted to a double, the result is 9.007199254740992E15.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.ToEngineeringString
member.summary:
Returns a string representation of this BigDecimal.
This representation always prints all significant digits of this value. If the scale is negative or if Scale - Precision >= 6 then engineering notation is used. Engineering notation is similar to the scientific notation except that the exponent is made to be a multiple of 3 such that the integer part is >= 1 and < 1000.
member.returns: Returns a string representation of this in engineering notation if necessary

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.ToInt16Exact
member.summary:
Returns this BigDecimal as a short value if it has no fractional part and if its value fits to the short range ([-2^{15}..2^{15}-1]).
If these conditions are not met, an ArithmeticException is thrown.
member.returns: Returns this BigDecimal as a short value

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.ToInt32
member.summary:
Returns this BigDecimal as an int value.
If the integral part of this is too big to be represented as an int, then this % 2^32 is returned.
member.returns: Returns this BigDecimal as an int value

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.ToInt32Exact
member.summary:
Returns this BigDecimal as an int value. Any fractional part is discarded.
Returns this BigDecimal as a int value if it has no fractional part and if its value fits to the int range ([-2^{31}..2^{31}-1]). If these conditions are not met, an ArithmeticException is thrown.
member.returns: This BigDecimal as a int value

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.ToInt64
member.summary:
Returns this BigDecimal as an long value. Any fractional part is discarded.
If the integral part of this is too big to be represented as an long, then this % 2^64 is returned.
member.returns: Returns this BigDecimal as a long value

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.ToInt64Exact
member.summary:
Returns this BigDecimal as a long value if it has no fractional part and if its value fits to the int range ([-2^{63}..2^{63}-1]).
If these conditions are not met, an ArithmeticException is thrown.
member.returns: this BigDecimal as a long value

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.ToPlainString
member.summary:
Returns a string representation of this BigDecimal.
No scientifi notation is used. This methods adds zeros where necessary. If this string representation is used to create a new instance, this instance is generally not identical to this as the precision changes. x.Equals(new BigDecimal(x.ToPlainString()) usually returns false. x.CompareTo(new BigDecimal(x.ToPlainString())} returns 0
member.returns: A string representation of this without exponent part.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.ToSingle
member.summary:
Returns this BigDecimal as a float value.
If this is too big to be represented as an float, then Float.POSITIVE_INFINITY or Float.NEGATIVE_INFINITY is returned.
member.returns: Returns this BigDecimal as a float value

remarks.para: Note, that if the unscaled value has more than 24 significant digits, then this decimal cannot be represented exactly in a float variable. In this case the result is rounded. For example, if the instance x1 = new BigDecimal("0.1") cannot be represented exactly as a float, and thus x1.Equals(new BigDecimal(x1.FloatValue()) returns false for this case. Similarly, if the instance new BigDecimal(16777217) is converted to a float, the result is 1.6777216E7.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.Ulp
member.summary:
Returns the unit in the last place (ULP) of this BigDecimal instance.
An ULP is the distance to the nearest big decimal with the same precision.para>
member.returns: Returns unit in the last place (ULP) of this BigDecimal instance

remarks.para: The amount of a rounding error in the evaluation of a floating-point operation is often expressed in ULPs. An error of 1 ULP is often seen as a tolerable error. For class BigDecimal, the ULP of a number is simply 10^(-scale). For example, {@code new BigDecimal(0.1).ulp()} returns {@code 1E-55}.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.ValueOf(System.Double)
member.summary:
Returns a new BigDecimal instance whose value is equal to value.
The new decimal is constructed as if the BigDecimal(String) constructor is called with an argument which is equal to Double.toString(val). For example, ValueOf("0.1")} is converted to (unscaled=1, scale=1), although the double 0.1 cannot be represented exactly as a double value. In contrast to that, a new BigDecimal(0.1) instance has the value 0.1000000000000000055511151231257827021181583404541015625 with an unscaled value 1000000000000000055511151231257827021181583404541015625}and the scale 55.
member.param: Double value to be converted to a {@code BigDecimal
member.exception: Thrown if Value is infinite or not a number

member.summary:
Returns true if Obj is a BigDecimal instance and if this instance is equal to this big decimal.
Two big decimals are equal if their unscaled value and their scale is equal. For example, 1.0 (10*10^(-1)) is not equal to 1.00 (100*10^(-2)). Similarly, zero instances are not equal if their scale differs.

If the integral part of this is too big to be represented as an int, then this % 2^32 is returned.
member.returns: Returns this BigDecimal as an int value

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.op_Implicit(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal)~System.Int64
member.summary:
Returns this BigDecimal as an long value. Any fractional part is discarded.
If the integral part of this is too big to be represented as an long, then this % 2^64 is returned.
member.returns: Returns this BigDecimal as a long value

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.op_Implicit(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal)~System.Single
member.summary:
Returns this BigDecimal as a float value.
If this is too big to be represented as an float, then Float.POSITIVE_INFINITY or Float.NEGATIVE_INFINITY is returned.
member.returns: Returns this BigDecimal as a float value

remarks.para: Note, that if the unscaled value has more than 24 significant digits, then this decimal cannot be represented exactly in a float variable. In this case the result is rounded. For example, if the instance x1 = new BigDecimal("0.1") cannot be represented exactly as a float, and thus x1.Equals(new BigDecimal(x1.FloatValue()) returns false for this case. Similarly, if the instance new BigDecimal(16777217) is converted to a float, the result is 1.6777216E7.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.op_Implicit(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal)~System.Double
member.summary:
Returns this BigDecimal as a double value.
If this is too big to be represented as an float, then Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY or Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY is returned.
member.returns: Returns this BigDecimal as a double value

remarks.para: Note, that if the unscaled value has more than 53 significant digits, then this decimal cannot be represented exactly in a double variable. In this case the result is rounded. For example, if the instance x1 = new BigDecimal("0.1") cannot be represented exactly as a double, and thus x1.Equals(new BigDecimal(x1.ToDouble()) returns false for this case. Similarly, if the instance new BigDecimal(9007199254740993L)c> is converted to a double, the result is 9.007199254740992E15.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.op_Implicit(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal)~VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger
member.summary:
Returns this BigDecimal as a big integer instance.
A fractional part is discarded.
member.returns: Returns this BigDecimal as a BigInteger instance

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.op_Implicit(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal)~System.String
member.summary:
Returns a canonical string representation of this BigDecimal.
If necessary, scientific notation is used. This representation always prints all significant digits of this value. If the scale is negative or if Scale - precision >= 6 then scientific notation is used.
member.returns: Returns a string representation of this in scientific notation if necessary

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.op_Implicit(System.Int64)~VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal
member.summary:
Constructs a new BigDecimal instance from the given long value.
The scale of the result is 0.
member.param: The long value to be converted to a BigDecimal instance

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.op_Implicit(System.Double)~VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal
member.summary:
Constructs a new instance from the 64bit double value.
The constructed big decimal is equivalent to the given double.
member.param: The double value to be converted to a instance
member.remarks:
For example, new BigDecimal(0.1) is equal to 0.1000000000000000055511151231257827021181583404541015625. This happens as 0.1 cannot be represented exactly in binary.
To generate a big decimal instance which is equivalent to 0.1 use the constructor.
member.exception: Thown if is infinity or not a number.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.op_Implicit(System.Int32)~VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal
member.summary:
Constructs a new BigDecimal instance from the given int value.
The scale of the result is 0.
member.param: The int value to be converted to a BigDecimal instance

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.op_Implicit(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger)~VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal
member.summary:
Constructs a new BigDecimal instance from the given BigInteger value.
The scale of the result is 0
member.param: Value to be converted to a BigDecimal instance

member.name: P:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.Precision
member.summary:
Returns the precision of this BigDecimal.
The precision is the number of decimal digits used to represent this decimal. It is equivalent to the number of digits of the unscaled value. The precision of 0 is 1 (independent of the scale).

member.name: P:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.Scale
member.summary:
Returns the scale of this BigDecimal.
The scale is the number of digits behind the decimal point. The value of this BigDecimal is the unsignedValue * 10^(-scale). If the scale is negative, then this BigDecimal represents a big integer.

member.name: P:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigDecimal.UnScaledValue
member.summary:
Returns the unscaled value (mantissa) of this BigDecimal instance as a BigInteger.
The unscaled value can be computed as this 10^(scale).

member.name: T:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.Logical
member.summary:
This class implements some logical operations over BigInteger.
The operations provided are:
Not
And
AndNot/>
Or/>
Xor/>

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.Logical.Not(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger)
member.summary:
Returns a new BigInteger whose value is ~Value.
The result of this operation is -this-1.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.Logical.And(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger,VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger)
member.summary: Computes the bit per bit operator between this number and the given one.
member.param: The value to be And'ed with X
member.returns: Returns a new BigInteger whose value is Value & X.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.Logical.AndNot(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger,VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger)
member.summary:
Returns a new BigInteger whose value is this & ~Value.
Evaluating x.AndNot(Value) returns the same result as x.And(Value.Not()).
member.param: Value to be Not'ed and then And'ed

member.summary: Returns a new BigInteger whose value is this ^ Value

member.name: T:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.Division
member.summary:
Static library that provides all operations related with division and modular arithmetic to .
Some methods are provided in both mutable and immutable way.
There are several variants provided listed below:
BigInteger Division and Remainder operations
Modular exponentiation between BigInteger
Modular inverse of a BigInteger numbers/>
BigInteger division and remainder by int

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.Division.Divide(System.Int32[],System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32)
member.summary:
Divides the array 'a' by the array 'b' and gets the quotient and the remainder.
Implements the Knuth's division algorithm. See D. Knuth, The Art of Computer Programming, vol. 2. Steps D1-D8 correspond the steps in the algorithm description.

member.name: M:VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.Division.DivideAndRemainderByInteger(VTDev.Libraries.CEXEngine.Numeric.BigInteger,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Computes the quotient and the remainder after a division by an int number
member.returns: Returns an array of the form [quotient, remainder]

member.summary:
Divides an array by an integer value. Implements the Knuth's division algorithm.
See D. Knuth, The Art of Computer Programming, vol. 2.

member.summary:
Performs modular exponentiation using the Montgomery Reduction.
It requires that all parameters be positive and the modulus be even. Based on theThe square and multiply algorithm and the Montgomery Reduction C. K. Koc - Montgomery Reduction with Even Modulus. The square and multiply algorithm and the Montgomery Reduction. ar.org.fitc.ref "C. K. Koc - Montgomery Reduction with Even Modulus"

summary.h3: An implementation of a Hash based Message Authentication Code: HMACFips 198-1.
summary.para: A HMAC as outlined in the NIST document: Fips 198-1Fips 198-1

item.description: Key size should be equal to digest output sizeRFC 2104.
Block size is the Digests engines block size.
Digest size is the Digest engines digest return size.
The Constructors DisposeEngine parameter determines if Digest engine is destroyed when is called on this class; default is true.

list.item: The method wraps the and DoFinal methods./>

item.description: The method resets the internal state.
RFC 2104: HMAC: Keyed-Hashing for Message Authentication.
Fips 198-1: The Keyed-Hash Message Authentication Code (HMAC).
Fips 180-4: Secure Hash Standard (SHS).
NMAC and HMAC Security: NMAC and HMAC Security Proofs.
Based on the Bouncy Castle Java Release 1.51 version.

summary.h3: PBKDF2: An implementation of an Hash based Key Derivation Function.
summary.para: PBKDF2 as outlined in ISO 18033-2 ISO 18033.

item.description: Can be initialized with a Digest or a Mac.
The Constructors DisposeEngine parameter determines if Digest engine is destroyed when is called on this class; default is true.
Salt size should be multiple of Digest block size.
Ikm size should be Digest hash return size.
Nonce and Ikm are optional, (but recommended).
ISO-18033-2: Specification.
RFC 2898: Specification.
Based on the Bouncy Castle Java Release 1.51 version.
